outcomes.title: Surfaces and Graphs
outcomes.description: Use traces and contours to describe the graphs of functions of two variables.
outcomes.template:
The graph and a contour plot of a function of two variables z = f(x,y) is shown. Note that the x-coordinates of points are given along the bottom of the contour plot and y-coordinates along the left.

Which of the following is the best choice for the function f(x,y)? For each choice, you must provide at least one reason that specifically references its traces, contours, or values for why it is or is not the best choice.

z={{choice0}}.

z={{choice1}}.

z={{choice2}}.

z={{choice3}}.

z={{choice4}}.

z={{surface}}

outcomes.title: Vector Arithmetic
outcomes.description: Compute and geometrically interpret sums, differences, scalar multiples, and magnitudes of vectors in n-dimensional space.
outcomes.template:
Let \mathbf{v}=\langle {{v0}}, {{v1}}, {{v2}}\rangle and \mathbf{w}=\langle {{w0}}, {{w1}}, {{w2}}\rangle.

Compute \mathbf{u}=({{a}})\mathbf{v} {{op}} ({{b}})\mathbf{w}.

\mathbf{u}=\langle {{u0}}, {{u1}}, {{u2}}\rangle.

What is the magnitude of \mathbf{u}?

|\mathbf{u}|={{mag}}.

Find a vector of magnitude 1 in the same direction as \mathbf{u}.

\frac{1}{|u|}\mathbf{u}=\langle {{unitu0}}, {{unitu1}}, {{unitu2}}\rangle.

Plot the projection of \mathbf{u} onto the xy-plane in terms of the projections of ({{a}})\mathbf{v} and ({{b}})\mathbf{w}, using the head-to-tail (i.e. parallelogram) method.

The projection of \mathbf{u} will have its tail at {{initp}} and its head at {{termp}}.

data.termp: the resultant of placing the tail of 1w at the head of -3v
the resultant of placing the tail of 3w at the head of -3v
the resultant of placing the tail of 3w at the head of -3v
the resultant of placing the tail of 1w at the head of 1v
the resultant of placing the tail of 3w at the head of 2v
the resultant of placing the tail of 1w at the head of 2v
the resultant of placing the tail of 3w at the head of -3v
the resultant of placing the tail of 3w at the head of 2v

outcomes.title: Vector Geometry
outcomes.description: Use dot products and cross products of vectors to compute quantities of geometric interest, including projections, angles, and areas.

outcomes.title: Parametrized Lines
outcomes.description: Determine parametric equations for a line in three-space.
outcomes.template:
Let \mathcal{L} denote the line in \mathbb{R}^3 that {{first_condition}} and {{second_condition}}.

Find parametric equations \begin{cases}x(t)& =\\ y(t)& =\\ z(t)& = \qquad\end{cases} for this line that satisfy \bigl( x(0),y(0),z(0) \bigr) = {{p}}.

\bigl( x(t),y(t),z(t) \bigr) = {{r1}}. (Answers may vary.)

Find a parametric vector equation \mathbf{r}(t) = \bigl( x(t) , y(t), z(t)\bigr) for this line that satisfies \mathbf{r}({{t}}) = {{p}}.

\mathbf{r}(t) = {{r2}}. (Answers may vary.)

data.first_condition: is the intersection of the plane x + 2y - z = 13

data.second_condition: is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(-10t - 34 , 12t + 40 , -4)

data.first_condition: is the intersection of the plane -y = -5

data.second_condition: is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(4t - 10 , 2t + 1 , -5)
is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(1 , 4t + 14 , -10t - 35)

data.first_condition: is the intersection of the plane -2x - 3y + 2z = 25
is the intersection of the plane -x - 3y + z = 7
is the intersection of the plane -x + y + z = 2

data.second_condition: is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(1 , -6t + 22 , 9t - 29)
is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(-2t - 3 , 1 , -2t + 1)

data.first_condition: is the intersection of the plane x - y - z = 8

data.second_condition: is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(6t + 23 , 6t + 22 , 3)
is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(-2t - 8 , -4t - 10 , -8)
is parallel to the line with parametric vector equation r(t)=(-2t + 2 , 4t - 19 , -4)

outcomes.title: Planes
outcomes.description: Find an equation for a plane in three-space defined either by three non-collinear points or by a point and a normal vector.
outcomes.template:
Consider the three points A={{A}}, B={{B}} and C={{C}}.

Find an equation for the plane containing the points {{A}}, {{B}} and {{C}}.

Since \overline{AB}\times\overline{AC}={{AB}}\times{{AC}}={{cross}}, we have that the plane can be defined by {{plane1}}, or \boxed{ {{plane1s}} }.

Find an equation for the plane parallel to the one found above, but which contains the point {{D}}.

This plane can be defined by {{plane2}}, or \boxed{ {{plane2s}} }..

outcomes.title: Intersections
outcomes.description: Find the intersection of lines and planes.
outcomes.template:
Consider lines \mathcal{L}_1={{Lu}}, \mathcal{L}_2 = {{Lv}}. Find their point of intersection, if they don't intersect, state so.

\mathcal{L}_1 passes through {{P}} when t={{tu}}. \mathcal{L}_2 passes through {{P}} when t={{tv}}. The point of intersection is {{P}}.

Find the plane orthogonal to {{planeV}} = {{k0}} containing \mathcal{L}_1={{Lu}}.

This plane is {{planecross}} = {{k1}} .

Parameterize the line that is the intersection of {{planeU}} = {{ku}} and {{planeV}} = {{kv}} .

This line is {{Lcross}} .

outcomes.title: Parameterized Curve
outcomes.description: Sketch and parameterize portions of oriented curves, including those defined by intersections of surfaces and those which involve circular motions.
outcomes.template:
Consider the curve parameterized by \langle {{f0}}, {{g0}}, {{h0}}\rangle.

Find the point on this curve corresponding to t={{t0}}

({{x0}}, {{y0}}, {{z0}}).

Plot the portion of this curve where -2 \leq t\leq 2.

Consider the surface determined by z=f(x,y)={{surface}}.

Parameterize the trace corresponding to {{tracev}}={{k1}}

({{f1}}, {{g1}}, {{h1}}).

Parameterize the trace corresponding to z={{k2}}

({{f2}}, {{g2}}, {{h2}}).

outcomes.title: Derivatives and Curvature
outcomes.description: Use derivatives to determine, and distinguish among, a parameterized curve’s tangent, speed, velocity, and acceleration.
outcomes.template:
Consider a particle whose position is parameterized by r(t)=\langle {{f0}}, {{g0}}, {{h0}}\rangle.

Find the position of the particle when t={{t0}}.

({{x0}}, {{y0}}, {{z0}}).

Find the velocity vector of the particle when t={{t0}} and it's magnitude.

Since r'(t)=\langle {{f1}}, {{g1}}, {{h1}}\rangle, the velocity vector at t={{t0}} is ({{vx}}, {{vy}}, {{vz}}) with magnitude {{vmag}}.

Parameterize the line tangent to the trajectory of the particle when t={{t0}}.

({{lx}}, {{ly}}, {{lz}}).

Find the acceleration vector of the particle when t={{t0}} and it's magnitude.

Since r''(t)=\langle {{f2}}, {{g2}}, {{h2}}\rangle, the velocity vector at t={{t0}} is ({{ax}}, {{ay}}, {{az}}) with magnitude {{amag}}.

outcomes.description: Simplify the sum of two monomials.
